posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Hi! In light of the many recent SysId help threads, I thought I’d put out this reminder that SysId is a supplemental tool intended to help fairly advanced users get the last bits of performance out of their mechanisms.

SysId is not supposed to replace manual tuning, especially not for users who haven’t yet fully mastered it.

If you cannot make sense of the SysId diagnostics panel, please: spend your time manually-tuning your mechanisms instead.  It will teach you more, and get you good results much more quickly than messing with a tool that you can’t troubleshoot.  You can come back to SysId later, in the offseason, once you better-understand what it is the tool is doing.

There are some improved diagnostics for the tool in the works (credit to @DeltaDizzy ), but these won’t change the fundamental nature of the thing.  Tools like SysId become useful only once you have enough intuition to sanity-check their results.  If you’re not there yet, that’s OK - it won’t make or break your season whether you have SysId-generated gains or manually-tuned ones.  I promise.

link_counts.title: What are your Programming pet peeves
PID sysid tunning max swerve main code

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Indeed another thing that Oblarg did, and all might want to consider:

In this section, we will tune a simple velocity controller for a flywheel. The tuning principles explained here will also work for almost any velocity control scenario. Flywheel Model Description: ...

There is a series of tutorials on doing manual tuning.

You still want to do this on your real mechanism too, but it should help bridge some gaps in understanding to make sure you have a sense of what to look for while tuning (either with sysid, or manually)

link_counts.title: Tuning a Flywheel Velocity Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Addendum: if you want to really understand where the SysId routine comes from and what it does, you should read the following:

The original whitepaper describing the regression methodology applied to differential drives

A description of the algorithm used to calculate feedback gains ( PID ) from feedforward gains (kV, kA)

Remember, SysId does two entirely separate things: a regression to determine the model, and an optimization to figure out the feedback gains to control it.

The regression is quite a bit simpler than the optimization, and even if you can’t make heads or tails of the second link I suggest that everyone using the tool read the first one.  The determination of feedforward gains is not magic - it is very much a high-school-level calculation, that many students could do themselves in a spreadsheet or scripting language given enough time and guidance.

@DeltaDizzy ’s new-and-improved documentation will include instructions for performing a version of the regression analysis manually in R, which is a very worthwhile exercise (and a good excuse to learn R!).

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
Additionally, if you do choose to use SysID after manually tuning:

SysID doesn’t automagically find kP or kD for you

If you don’t want to read on, my advice is ignore the kP and kD SysID provides and tune manually .  Otherwise…

The kP it spits out also depends on manually-enterable values, specifically, Max Acceptable Error and Max Control Effort.

I’ve seen this get missed several times over several years.  Since SysID gives values for things like kS and kV, it’s natural to see the kP it spits out and go,

“oh cool, it figured that out too” “wow, the kP it came up with is very different from the one I was using.” “huh, I guess the kP is much lower with this feedforward I’m now using” (which is usually true, but not for this reason)

Until you’ve entered values for Max Acceptable Error and Max Control Effort, do not simply trust the kP and kD provided by SysID.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
usbcd36:

Until you’ve entered values for Max Acceptable Error and Max Control Effort, do not simply trust the kP and kD provided by SysID.

LQR is guaranteed to be stable regardless of cost-function weighting, so it should never do anything outright bad no matter what’s been put in for effort and tolerance.

What can give you unstable/unusable results is entering the wrong loop frequency or signal delay.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
The usual failure mode I see is that the resulting kP is far too small, since the default Max Acceptable Error is often far too large.  If you don’t know that you have to set the Max Acceptable Error (and the UI doesn’t hint at it; the field looks like another output), it won’t give the results you desire.

Case in point: students the other day were iterating using SysID (tuned manually first) and went, “wow, that kP is tiny”, at which point I noted to them that the Max Acceptable Error was set to ~0.3 rotations for a single-rotation mechanism (direct output, not motor shaft).

I’m just saying: garbage in, garbage out.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

What can give you unstable/unusable results is entering the wrong loop frequency or signal delay.

So wouldn’t a best practice be sysId with a codebase that only focuses on the motor you’re interested in?

Or possibly disconnect the other devices from the network while sysIding?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Not necessarily, no.  What matters is how the motor behaves under operating conditions.

You might get better data that way, if the rest of your robot program is slow, but if that’s how the code is when controlling the motor then cleaning up the data won’t necessarily improve your control.

SysId estimates signal delay for you, anyhow.  You should compare that estimate against your settings, and make sure the feedback analyzer is set to take it into account.

On-motor-controller loops will typically have less delay than on-RIO loops.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Oblarg:

What can give you unstable/unusable results is entering the wrong loop frequency or signal delay.

So this begs the question.  SysId will enter values for position measurement delay and velocity measurement delay.  Should I set those to what the loop frequency and signal delay are from a calculation from the settings or use what sysId determined?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Try both and see.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

and then really large number for velocity tolerance

I mean, you’ll still want velocity feedback to stay on the profile. Position-only control will lag behind.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: Sure but the PIDController (REV in this case only uses a position measurement

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Code Snippet

Mostly for a sanity check.  Using an Elevator Profile, with an elevator feedfoward, but REV’s PID controller.  Would a profile PIDController from WPILIB be better in this case?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Gotcha it took me a minute.

Also I’m always impressed by your quick markdown equations writing.

So if say I wanted centimeter accuracy on an elevator I’d have max position error be 0.01;

Is there some wisdom on how close the velocity error should be for position control.   0.1 meters, same as max position error?

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: When 3512 used LQR, we made the velocity tolerance 10x larger than the position tolerance. It really comes down to how well you want the velocity to track the profile.
